Spotlight on...the Emperor of JapanJ Hirohito's change in

indication of what's happened to Japan itsolf...with regard

Probably the most extraordinary sight in post-war Japan is
the Emperor, for the very reason that he can now be seen.
Up to a decade ago, the Japanese people bowed low? and averted
their eyes when the
Imperial Presence passed in a car or even on a train. They
would not have dared look at the descendant of the world’s
oldest unbroken imperial dynasty—124th descendant of the
Sun Goddess. But, after the war, the people look straight
at him: and they see an unassuming man with a toothbrush
mustache, thick glasses, a shy smile, and a hesitant walk.
And now they like him...the rotogravure pages on Sunday often
picture tho Emperor at home. Much like the English Sunday
Supplements which dote on royalty. (PAUSE) Well, Hirohito,
his Emperess and the crown prince, Akihito...represent or
symbolize unity in the Japanese traditional family life.
On New Years Day I happened to be one of the many thousand
who swarmed the Palace Grounds. An estimated 100,000 Japanese
came to pay their respects as citizens and to look directly
at their emperor. The man who inspires this devotion is
a curious mixture of ancient tradition and modern tastes.
